subject: Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... invoking ... However, by breaking the method down into parts, you can: * reduce the permutations to test (by making some permutations trivial) * make your
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Iliya Agoshkov wrote:
>
> > Or I don't need to test em at all (cause they are tested through the
> > test of 'public search(...)' method)??
>
> Half right. You do need to test these methods. You test them by
invoking
> the public search method. Test methods do not need to directly invoke a
> method in order to test it, provided that the methods they do invoke
> ultimately reach into the methods being tested.

However, by breaking the method down into parts, you can:
* reduce the permutations to test (by making some permutations trivial)
* make your test code simpler to understand; and
* stumble across re-useable abstractions.

Not always, but in many cases, this will be the case.

You will still need that test on the public search() method, of
course. But one test should suffice - you wouldn't need several, each
with different values (for example, to test the null conditions)

Robert.
